Situation1: They openly turn to each other for help in a difficult personal moment.
Situation2: The partner received disappointing feedback at work and is visibly upset.
Story:
My phone buzzed twice in quick succession. First, a message from my sister: “Can you come over? I really need to talk.” She never asked for help unless it was serious. I could hear her voice trembling through the text, and I knew she was struggling with her breakup. Before I could reply, my girlfriend called, her voice shaky. “I got the feedback. It was awful. Can you come over?” She’d been working so hard for this promotion, and I could hear the tears she was trying to hold back.

I stared at my phone, heart pounding. My sister and I always promised to be there for each other, no matter what. But my girlfriend needed me too—she’d always said I was her safe place when things got tough. I felt pulled in two directions, both expecting me to be their support, both needing me right now. My mind raced, guilt and worry tangling together as I tried to figure out how I could possibly be there for both of them at the same time.
